body:
$!You should check your employees are entitled to work in the UK. You could be [prosecuted](/penalties-for-employing-illegal-workers "Penalties for employing illegal workers") if you employ illegal workers.$!

You should check all your employees and must not discriminate against anyone because of their nationality.

Check that:

- the documents aren't expired (except UK passports, which can be expired)
- photos in the documents look like the employee
- the date of birth on the document seems consistent with the employee's appearance
- the visa covers the type of work they'll be doing (including any limit on the number of hours they can work)
- if 2 documents have different names on, make sure there's a good reason, eg marriage or divorce

There are examples of documents on the [UK Border Agency website (PDF, 2.9MB).](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/documents/employersandsponsors/preventingillegalworking/currentguidanceandcodes/comprehensiveguidancefeb08.pdf?view=Binary "Comprehensive Guidance for Employers on Preventing Illegal Working"){:rel="external"}

## Make a copy of the documents

s1. Make a copy that can't be changed, eg a photocopy, a scan or a recordable CD that can't be overwritten.
s2. For passports, copy the front page and any page with the employee's details on including endorsements, eg a work visa or Certificate of Entitlement to Right of Abode in the UK.
s3. For biometric residence permits, copy both sides.
s4. Keep copies for 2 years after the person stops working for you.  

Make sure you follow the law when it comes to data protection.

##Birth, adoption, registration or naturalisation certificates

Birth, adoption, registration or naturalisation are only proof of eligibility to work in the UK if they were issued in the:

- UK
- Channel Islands
- Isle of Man
- Republic of Ireland

A certificate on its own is not proof of eligibility to work in the UK. Another document will be needed, eg passport.

###Birth certificate

A birth certificate must show the name of the holder and at least one of their parents. The certificate must be an original (not a copy).

###Adoption certificate

An adoption certificate must show the name of at least one of the adoptive parents.

###Naturalisation certificate

A naturalisation certificate must describe the holder as a British citizen.

##Certificate of Entitlement to the Right of Abode

A Certificate of Entitlement to the Right of Abode is only valid if it's in a current, valid passport.

For help, contact the UKBA Sponsorship and Employers' Helpline.

**UKBA Sponsorship and Employers' Helpline**  
0300 123 4699  
<UKBApublicenquiries@ukba.gsi.gov.uk>
$C
overview: Check an employee's permission to work in the UK and make sure you're not prosecuted for employing an illegal worker
title: Check an employee's right to work documents
